summary: Yasmin (Nathalia Ramos), Jade (Janel Parrish), Sasha (Logan Browning) and Cloe (Skyler Shaye) are best friends and fashion mavens. The well-dressed quartet faces unexpected challenges to a lifelong bond when each one enters Carry Nation High, where senior Meredith Baxter Dimly (Chelsea Staub) rules the school's social cliques with an iron fist. As peer pressure threatens to divide the girls, they must learn how to band together and how to achieve true empowerment.

reviews.content: The worst of characters, the worst of plot, the worst of messages, the worst of stereotypes, the worst of song numbers, the worst of background music, the worst of writing, the worst of everything. This is by far one of the worst movies ever made.

This movie is truly a cinematic masterpiece. Anyone who says otherwise is wrong, grow up. From start to finish, this movie is impeccable, the filming, the acting, the soundtrack… (like come on, Bratitude has to be the greatest song ever made!!)  There is no movie which leaves me with such high levels of serotonin. I cannot fault these girls, or the writers! The incredibly racist stereotypes are so easy to ignore when the soundtrack is as good as it is! Please watch this movie, please give it 5 stars, you're delusional if you don't enjoy it. I'll have you know I studied a movie in my english class once so I KNOW what i'm talking about. I adore this movie, I need it injected in my veins

11/10 movie. the storyline does the franchise justice but keeps itself as a strong stand-alone product. i recommend this movie to all and i believe my life is better after watching this brilliant film. my outlook towards others and the world around me will never be the same and i believe without chloe, sasha, jade, and yasmin this would never be within reach or reason. thank you Sean McNamara for directing this movie into life. pls listen to bratitude on all streaming platforms. have a good day :D
the girls that get it get it and tje girls that don't, don't. If you don't get it it's because you can't have fun. This movie was a masterpiece

I liked it! I thought it was a nice movie for young women and teens. Its a movie about friendship, staying true to yourself and being who you want to be. I really don't see the "dubious morals" noted in the overall critic formulation but that's critics for you. Has lots of corny lines and poor performances here and there but its still has lots of funny moments and good chemistry between Yasmin and her romance.

I remember watching some of this on TV back in 2008. While, as a movie based off of a toyline targeted towards girls, it was something of a foregone conclusion that this wasn't my thing, part of me tried to keep watching but it just came off as rather forgettable and bland. Many years later, I decide to cut corners by watching some caustic critics review it because I'd rather not be caught actually watching the film and dealing with some awkward questions and it seems I made the right call all those years ago. From its appearance, it appeared to be a truly shallow film with obnoxious humour, bad performances, questionable messages and a story that doesn't feel like it does a very good job encouraging its demographic to go buy Bratz dolls. One could argue that it actually brought out the worst in teen comedies (albeit a family-oriented one, rather than a pure PG-13 one). Transformers is the definitive victor here for best live-action film of 2007 based off of a toyline (and both had Jon Voight in them as well!).

I loved this movie growing up, and I love it now. For me it's like a feel good movie and definitely interesting enough to keep my attention. I love the message it gives. The outfits the girls wear aren't exactly as fashionable as I would have imagined for Bratz to wear. However, it's an all around wholesome movie and I will definitely continue watching it again and again.

It was a perfect experience like mean girls but sometimes being this type of brat is good people who didn't like are stupid just because it is a child movie it says it is bad really never seen something's so strange I respect the opinion but I feel like the bad reviews are shit

This movie keeps the spirit of the Bratz franchise perfectly. The outfits are true to the style of the original dolls, and the personalities are too. True fans of the Bratz Universe will appreciate the dedication to detail and the expansion of the lore that this movie provides. Some of the scenes are stereotypical and disappointing (especially the depiction of Jade's mom), but overall this is a display of very healthy family/friend relationships. The focus is on friendship, not on boys or popularity. The characters are dynamic, and the mean girl is delightfully mean. The undertones are whimsically Marxist. The musical numbers are incredible, and the outfits are insane. If you want to think and learn, watch Schindler's List. If you want to eat cookie dough and laugh with your friends, watch Bratz.
Iconic throwback if you're into 2000s girly girl bs

Let me just say, I've seen Human Centipede. The reason I mention this is because compared to this movie, Human Centipede is the Avenger's of films. The acting is level Beetlejuice, I appreciate your effort but goodness gracious if I could collect 7 Dragon Balls I would wish for my time back...
Worse movie ever made, they made Yasmine look horrible and she was the prettiest doll. Horrible, awful, disgusting. Wate of money and time.
One of my favourite movies no matter what others say.
A movie that sparked the rise of feminism. The film defined an entire generation's childhood, teaching young girls the beauty of their differences and the power of friendship.
Really awesome movie!!

I mean, obviously Bratz isn't good by any means and it's not so bad it's good, but I showed this to my 7 year old niece and she loved it. So I guess, if you have a daughter or niece that's in the 4 to 10 age range, this movie will certainly entertain them.
its not a classic,but its entertaining/amusing.seen a lot worse than this by far.
DO NOT WATCH THIS TERRIBLE MOVIE ITS THE WORST MY SISTER IS A PSYCHOPATH AND LIKE THIS BULLCRAP ABSOLUTLEY TERRIBLE!!!!!!!!!!!!ITS LIKE THEY HAD A CHECKLIST OF CLICHES TO PUT IN!!!!!!!!!!!
Single handedly the best film of our generation. It is an insult that rotten tomatoes would give it such a low score. The acting and singing are absolutely exceptional and phenomenal.
This is really bad. Really really bad
This was my childhood movie
One of my fav movies, watched it a million times
Great cast but no matter how hard I tried I just don't like this movie. I was really excited to see this too, because of how much I loved the Bratz growning up. Disappointing. ??

As a past lover of the Bratz, when this film first came out, I was really excited to see it and see my favourite characters humanized. I had watched the TV show, the animated movies and played some of the video games so I hoped high. Granted, I was 15 when I first saw it and I did somewhat enjoy it, but since it was one of my favourite things still, I didn't mind the parts I was unsure of.

Watching it again now, though, I see the huge glaring problems. The acting by the majority of actors is pretty awful (example, Chloe in the shop admitting she doesn't have money for a new outfit). The story itself is dumbed down to your average teen high school movie but its morals are twisted and confusing. The music is pretty terrible. The worst part, personally, was that all of the fantastic parts of the Bratz, the interesting adventures, the morals that occasionally popped up to teach you about friendship and life, Burdine Maxwell and the Tweevils (who, in all honesty, could have been horrible or amazingly campy in a live action remake). Basically, everything larger than life and interesting about the Bratz was removed and replaced with flimsy, stereotypical backstories and personalities that are impossible to relate to or connect with in most senses.

For a child or a young teenager who likes Bratz, this is enjoyable. For anyone else, it's pretty awful.
Well directed bad it's good film.
Its just an another crappy Hollywood high school movie
I'll never get those two hours of my life back!!!

why does this exist? This movies is so cliche and boring and even though the characters are supposed to be the "Awesome heroes of the movie" The really are just "Bratz". Do yourself a favor and don't watch this

When released, I had high expectations, surprisingly. - It isn't a bad movie, but all it's about is cliches, shoes and nails. - For a film about four teen girls, it lacked empowerment. It was a fabulous mess.

Let me start off with this, as a fan of the brat dolls and a few a the animated movies I always wondered if they were to make a live action movie what would it be like. But I can say after seeing this movie it is really cheezy, stupid and not on the level of bratz awesomeness. The casting of the main 4 girls is on point, but everyone else is just in the movie to be filler. My main issue with this movie is its dumbass  villian. Are you serious? A spoiled blonde bitch  named Marilyn who is the daughter of the principal. Give me a break! Why were none of the other females given their brat names it kinda seemed like they just made it up. Also another thing that irritated me was the brat boyz (omg) Dylan isn't black in this movie and they made him deaf how stupid is that and where is kobe and eithan or even motorcycle cade? They really screwed the pooch on the guys in this movie. Overall this movie needed to be about the brat girls in high school getting ready for their senior prom with the also popular brat boyz alongside, and develop their struggles with adulthood, love and friendship as high school draws to a close. I wanted this to be fun, smart and emotional and got neither. This should've been great.
I think my favorite part was when the Hispanic girl walks downstairs and there's just a sombrero-sporting mariachi band in her kitchen.
This movie is FREAKING TERRIBLE!!!, there's no other film that's more horrible than this piece of tween crap.
This movie is the worst!

Took the Mean Girls idea to the next level but without what people liked about mean girls. Not a film I (As an 18 year old male) would admit to watching. Has it's points when it's good to watch. Spent most of the film thinking which one of the Bratz I prefer.
hate me yall, but I have to say I really enjoyed this film

If Bratz: The movie can be summed up in a word, it should Vain, or shallow, or better yet, insensitive. It shows all the teen movie clichés and stereotypes at their worst. It has no pure message other than "Girls are cool!". And the materialism is so bad, it feels like it's trolling the audience.
It must be left to tween girls and tween girls alone.

Offensive and stereotypical on virtually every level, Bratz is an exercise in patience, a High School Musical ripoff and a display that the main four protagonists are actually shallow, unappealing "heroes" (and I say so with a grain of salt).

Perfection takes time.

The Bratz arrive on the scene as freshmen in high school and an older established clique sees them as a threat and tries to break them up.  They work with different social classes to try and split the Bratz into new cliques putting their alliance at risk.  Can the girl's friendship withhold the assassination attempt on their popularity?

"You don't sound def."
"You don't look ignorant but don't judge a book, right?"

Sean McNamara, director of Soul Surfer, Raise Your Voice, Spare Parts, Race to Space, Hollywood Chaos, and 3 Ninjas: High Noon at Mega Mountain, delivers Bratz.  The storyline for this picture is below average and a huge downgrade from similar genre films like Mean Girls.  The acting is mediocre and a hair above made for television quality.

"Keep talking, someday you'll say something intelligent." 

My daughter and I have been watching these animated movies off Netflix so we gave this live feature a chance.  I wouldn't say this is any better than the cartoon movies...they're all bad.  I recommend skipping these films, animated or live action.

"Don't you need a license to be that ugly?"

Grade: D
Possibly one of the worst films I've ever seen. Poor story line, annoying characters and the 'singing' that goes on throughout is enough to make you want to punch someone.

I wonder what it would be like to live day-by-day knowing you had participated in the creation of  the film adaptation of Bratz. You know, those dolls with the freakish lips and faces that dress with lower class than the "Me so horny!" Vietnamese hooker from Full Metal Jacket. Yes, those dolls.

One immediate question this film poses is, "How does one create a film based on a line of dolls that dress like Vegas strip hookers?" Or, there's also the questions, "Who the hell funded this film?" and "Who thought this was a wise investment?" There are many questions, with answers I don't think I'll ever get.

Going back to my first paragraph, I wonder what it must be like to be in director Sean McNamara's shoes. What could have possibly drawn this man to this project? Even taking into account his extensive directorial credits that include Disney Channel, Nickelodeon, and Cartoon Network episodes, what could possibly make anyone with such credits for directing programs for children want to take on a project that was destined to fail from the first pitch that there should be a film based on this particular brand of dolls?

I wonder if perhaps it was money being offered. But even so, what sort of monetary offering would be enough to entice anyone to direct something like this? Sure, you have the money, but you have the eternal shame in knowing that you helped birth one of the worst films ever made. But, this theory doesn't really hold water with me through even just a quick browsing of his work - specifically, his films.

A check of his filmography shows a strong leaning towards dramas, including ones with a faith angle and uplifting storylines, too. Though they received "meh" reviews from critics, his work with Soul Surfer and Spare Parts seem to be very well received by audiences. Hoovey seems to be decently received. He also directed a drama set during the Civil War which was met with mixed reviews called Field Of Lost Shoes, and even has a fantasy film coming out later this year called The Moon And The Sun which does sound a bit interesting, admittedly, considering its oddball premise. This to me, even though I have not seen his other work, shows signs of a much more ambitious director who has many ideas and lofty goals, complete with some solid fan followings for his works.

Plus, if his website's biography is to be believed, it raises more questions about why he directed this film. From this biography, I learned that the age of 12, during a trip to Ireland, his father bought him a super-8 camera. And as the plane taxied down the runway, he recorded it. This simple moment was apparently enough to inspire him to want to become a film-maker. I also wonder what else made him want to become a film-maker.

Every film-maker has their ambitions and inspirations, so what were his? Did he want to be the next great American (Maybe even international) director who would influence a new generation of film-makers and have film scholars talking for decades about his work? Did he want to create film classics? Or, was it perhaps something more modest, like being an indie director with creative freedoms and explorations into ideas mainstream films wouldn't allow for, complete with a small but dedicated fanbase? What were his inspirations? Classic American films? European or Asian art house films, perhaps? Or maybe, much like Quentin Tarantino, his inspirations are eclectic, obscure cult films? What were his goals? What were his inspirations?

I'm desperate to find out how and why. How did whatever goals, inspirations, or moments in life all lead to such a tragedy of film-making that had absolutely no hope of being remotely good? What went wrong? What led you to this point, Mr. McNamara? I don't think I've ever had a bad film confound me so much, and seen some major shit. But even with films that I hate more so than this one, they still had loftier goals and ideas that might have had some potential behind them. This is truly one of those rare cases where the idea was utterly hopeless. In fact, I haven't had a film make me ponder so much about its meanings since the Yasujiro Ozu masterpiece, Late Spring. Bratz is the antithesis to a film like Late Spring - it makes you ponder and contemplate for horrified and bewildered reasons, like trying to make sense of a tragic, senseless death.

The film focuses on 4 racially-stereotyped friends: Cloe, the bland blonde-haired white girl, Yasmin, the girl who's so Mexican there's a mariachi band in the house, her and her mother sing "La Cucaracha" at one point in the film, has an annoying brother with a thick Spanish accent, and there's also a Chevy Impala in their driveway (As if to remind you, "Hey, did you know that they're Mexicans?"), Jade, the smart Asian, and Sasha, the smart black girl whose parents are divorced.

The girls have been the best of friends ever since they were little and talk so much that they even skype one another. The girls are also obsessed with fashion and constantly discuss their outfits with one another. The girls are now getting ready to go to high school, where they assume that they'll all still be the best of friends.

But, as it turns out, that won't be the case, thanks to the principal's daughter, Meredith Baxter, who inexplicably has a dictatorial-style reign over the school and social cliques. Soon, the girls are split into different social cliques: Cloe joins the soccer team and immediately becomes only friends with the soccer team, Sasha becomes a cheerleader and only hangs out with other cheerleaders, Jade thanks to her stereotype, joins the science club and only hangs out with other members of the club, and Yasmin joins journalism, though she is most upset by this change events. It also turns out that Yasmin has singing talent, and with help from a deaf kid who is apparently a musical prodigy himself, she starts to grow in her talent. All the girls also meet attractive boys in their respective clubs.

2 years later in high school, and after being separated from one another, clumsy Yasmin inadvertently starts a food fight that results in all 4 girls being sent to detention after a statue of the principal is damaged during the food fight. After briefly hating one another for ending up in this situation, they become friends again, determined to end the cliques and get everyone to hang out together, resulting in a series of confrontations with the bitchy Meredith and planning a musical number for the upcoming talent show.

The storyline should have been a light, fluffy, albeit stupid bit of comedic fun. But even at the most basic levels, the story is completely doomed, which is made worse by how badly this film botches its messages about social cliques, self-esteem, and friendship. There is no reason to root for any of the characters as they are all soulless stereotypes which believe that through fashion and musical numbers, people will be brought together. No, Bratz. No they won't. The storyline makes me ponder the mental states of 3 - count 'em - 3 writers of this utter abortion, especially with all the stereotypes, poor messages, questionable role models, and complete lack of anything resembling a modicum of quality. The story is of such low quality that my brain felt like it was shutting down because of how the story will do absolutely nothing to engage it. You know how some people say that they would rather watch paint dry, and throw it around too often when discussing something they hate? Here, that would not be just throwing it around. Watching paint dry would literally be more stimulating than paying attention to this story.

I wonder how desperate an aspiring actor would have to be to agree to be in a film like this. Are you really so desperate to make a name for yourself in Hollywood that you would star in this film? You'd have less shame appearing in hardcore porn or bizarre fetish videos than you would starring in Bratz. Hell, I wouldn't be surprised if the cast was left with severe PTSD and found themselves locked in the padded room of an insane asylum for the rest of their lives after starring in this film. At a minimum, if I had starred in this film, I would have gone into hiding and never speak to anyone again out of shame.

The acting is horrible, but very difficult to properly describe. In fact, I will never be able to fully describe it to you. Well, to start off with the actresses, imagine the most irritating depictions of high school or college girls you've ever seen, or even just of prissy, fashion-obsessed girls you've ever seen in films. Now take those irritations you've felt and multiply them at least one hundred fold. Those are the performances given by the actresses in this film. They give performances that are bad beyond any earthly word. I don't even know if the darkest depths of Hell have a proper word for this sort of bad acting.

The other cast members are hardly any better, and continuing his downward spiral, Jon Voight appears in this film as the principal, and seems to have given up any semblance of respect he once had for acting. He gives one of the most hollow, soulless, dead-behind-the-eyes performances I've ever seen in films.

The acting is bad past the point of extraordinary, and crosses into the realm of legendary. You won't believe it, and you can't describe it to others. It is something that must be witnessed, but that would be too cruel a task to do.

There is no entertainment. There is literally nothing of redeeming value to be found. There's hardly a story, there are no likable or living characters, there is no funny humor, every song and dance number is excruciating (And this is coming from someone who gave Xanadu 5/5 stars and Grease 2 4/5 stars), the messages negate themselves, and it's overall an annoying, boring, and soul-sucking experience to endure. Have you ever known what it's felt like to watch a film so bad that it feels like it's sucking out the will to live? That's what Bratz will do to you, I shit you not. I hated the characters and hoped that they would all die, so the film would end faster, or perhaps that I would die and the agony would be over.

Though I would talk about the humor in a longer paragraph, I'm not going to. It is unspeakably bad.

Shortly before he died, Roger Ebert released his final list of the 10 best films he had ever seen. One of them was Citizen Kane. In the brief section about Citizen Kane, he talked about he and other film scholars spent several hours studying every single frame of that film. EVERY FRAME. I would never do that, no matter how much I loved a film. But it wouldn't take that kind of examination to tell you that every single frame of Bratz is a complete failure. Just pause the film at any point and try to find something of value in that still frame. You can't. There is nothing.

Bratz has now cemented itself as being not only one of the 10 worst comedies, musicals, chick flicks, and family films, it has now gone down as one of the 10 all-time worst films I have ever seen, period. Save your sanity. Save your soul. Save yourself. Once you watch Bratz, you will not come out of it the same person you were before. It is a life-changing, unforgettable bad film that will haunt me for the rest of my days, as I forever try to figure out how something so horrible and misconceived was ever allowed to exist or be pitched to studios in the first place. It is one of the ultimate tragedies of bad film-making. A film so heinous, it could be reclassified as a war crime or at least, an inhumane form of torture by the Geneva Convention.
horribly cliche, horribly acted, horribly sung, and yes, the characters do have brat-titude.

Completely horrible film. Nobody , child or adult would enjoy this 2007 film. This is aimed at children 6-10, but includes consumerism , racial stereo types , sexism , rebellion against parents, unrealistic expectations, and discrimination against disabled people (specifically headgear). That was only in the first 15 minutes. Along with all the horrible features, it has an overdone, cliche , and boring plot .Also, it doesn't eve go with the dolls back round at all. Overall , this is a crappy movie that N&K do not recommend.
Parents beware-- this movie will make your children stupid
I'm ashamed that I've watched this. I'm more ashamed I didn't hate it. Well, not all of it.
love it how they never give even someone brings them down
In all honesty, it's not that bad. And very entertaining. No joke, just watch it.
